conclusion: Determine the time interval between the release of the steel balls and the distance traveled by the balls.
Know the distances AB and BC and the time interval between the releases.
Distance AB = 15 cm and distance BC = 20 cm.
Time interval between the releases is 0.1 seconds.
Distance traveled by the balls increases uniformly due to constant acceleration down the incline.
Distance traveled by a body in uniform acceleration is given by s = ut + (1/2)at^2.
Let the time taken for the ball at position A to reach position B be t1 and the time taken for the ball at position B to reach position C be t2.
Distance AB is traveled in time t1, so AB = (1/2)a(t1 + 0.1)^2 - (1/2)a(t1)^2 = 15 cm.
Distance BC is traveled in time t2, so BC = (1/2)a(t2 + 0.1)^2 - (1/2)a(t2)^2 = 20 cm.
Simplify the equation for AB: 0.1at1 = 15 - 0.005a implies at1 = 150 - 0.05a.
Simplify the equation for BC: 0.1at2 = 20 - 0.005a implies at2 = 200 - 0.05a.
Solve the equation at1 = 150 - 0.05a for a: a = 150/(t1 + 0.05).
Substitute a = 150/(t1 + 0.05) into the equation at2 = 200 - 0.05a.
Since t2 = t1 + 0.1, substitute t2 into the equation: 150(t1 + 0.1) = 200t1 + 2.5.
Determine the number of balls in front of ball A: ball at A was released 2.5 seconds ago.
Balls are released every 0.1 seconds, number of balls released in 2.5 seconds is 2.5/0.1 = 25.
